name: Alyssa Walton
reason: I am a black woman who has taken advantage of the scholarship program here. Diversity and inclusion are important to me and I’d like it to continue here at Artshack

name: Vannesa  De Anda
reason:
I am a former staff member at Artshack and can not even begin to describe how much love I have for the community, staff, teachers and members. They are what make Artshack a special place and are some of the most beautiful, passionate, and insightful individuals I have ever met. I quit and moved away from New York at the end of last year. Unfortunately, the current state of affairs at Artshack does not come as a surprise. I worked at Artshack for four years and watched it go through many changes as it took on growth at an incredibly rapid pace. With each new renovation and expansion the continuous, heightened sense of urgency and overall feeling of tension also grew. I believe it is essential for Artshack, those in charge in harmony with the community, to revisit the mission and remember the goal - to make ceramic arts more accessible to people of all abilities and ages. As an anti-racist, queer-affirming organization, it is the responsibility of the Executive Director and the Board to create a space where staff, teachers, and the broader community feel safe, seen, and heard. Open and transparent discourse is essential.

I stand in solidarity with my Artshack family and community.

name: Clémence Audic
reason:
I stand up for and behind the Artshack community, which is made by its people.
That space, ceramic studios and café included, is very special. I am a regular at the café, and it has been to me a place of friendly and familiar faces in a new city and neighbourhood where I was settling. I have admired what that space is made of, cherished its staff members, and supported its values.

Today, the people making Artshack feel that the organisation and leadership are not aligned anymore with its mission and core values. It's a crucial time for discussion, evaluation, and accountability. Everyone in that community should be seen and heard. I hope this can be done with all the transparency, respect, and mindfulness that space and its individuals deserve.

name: Ashni M
reason: I stand in solidarity with the Artshack community looking for more transparency and accountability! I switched from BKLYN Clay to Artshack because I believed in the mission. I think it’s not too late to get back to the values / mission of Artshack that drew so many of us to this creative, silly, community space.

name: Rebecca Dunwoody
reason: I love exploring my ceramic practice at Artshack and chose it amongst Brooklyn studios because I believed in its mission. I don't want to work in a place that I don't feel positive about supporting and am concerned with the actions of the ED.

name: Bianca Mońa
reason: The People Shall Govern, South African anti-apatheid mantra

name: Mia Becker
reason: If Artshack Brooklyn claims to be a nonprofit that is anti-racist and queer-affirming organization why is it not listening to member and leadership who is of color and queer? You fundamentally cannot claim these tenants if your organization is actually a dictatorship run by a white woman who is unwillingly to reflect and learn how to do better.

name: Kaia Smith
reason: Given that the mission of Artshack is about COMMUNITY and work towards anti-racism practices and active DEI education and representation, I am appalled to see those that hold positions of power in the organization work against these principles. “Careful consideration and ongoing engagement with the community” needs to be more than just empty words by the ED and board.

name: Carol Song
reason: There is no where like Artshack, anywhere…and that is because of the incredible staff we have been so lucky to have met. It’s the staff who upholds and embraces this mission and who our children are inspired by and in community with. We feel how special it is and hope the mission doesn’t change!

name: lauren stander
reason:
i’ve been a student at artshack over the last two years, most of the time through the work-study program. it has allowed me to participate in a craft i couldn’t afford otherwise, which i remain grateful for. i have also gotten to know many wonderful students and teachers in the artshack community. the kindness, generosity, and collective spirit in the studio has kept me coming back and helps ground me in a practice.

reading through the timeline of events and documentation of what’s been happening behind the scenes portrays a different working environment than i would expect. i can’t know the full context of conversations that i wasn’t part of, and realize there are voices we haven’t heard to piece together the overall story. but with the information presented there seems to be a mission drift happening, and the deviation from artshack’s founding principles has reached a tipping point. i was struck by proposed changes like interns not being included in staff meetings - separating them from the community they give their time to, and depriving them of workplace learning/growth opportunities. i also believe that the role of a development leader in an organization like artshack should NOT be limited to admin work like grant proposals, maintaining databases, and compiling reports. creative approaches are needed to not only *financially* develop artshack, but to continuously evaluate its relationship with bed stuy, celebrate diversity, and keep evolving harmoniously as neighbors and artists.

i’ve worked my entire career at nonprofits, so unfortunately this tension and turmoil is familiar. i know what it’s like to have a colleague disappear, to feel confused and disheartened by organizational “restructuring”. i also know positive changes CAN come from these moments when there is true accountability and collaborative rebuilding. please do not let artshack slip away into the nonprofit industrial complex!

name: Nicole Gurganious
role: Bed-Stuy Community Member; Student; Parent; Ally

name: Rebecca Rambarran
reason: You write on your website that you are “developing accountability as an anti-racist, queer affirming organization…” how can that be the case when the ED is not willing to listen to employees and community members who have invested time and energy to create the space and community that artshack is today? A business built around social justice beliefs should stick to them. Diverting from your business messaging is a very odd choice. It’s giving Google dropping “do no evil” from their slogan.

name: Jay M
reason: Artshack should be accessible to everyone in the neighborhood. Countless people have already been displaced and priced out of this community. Artshack ought to do the opposite.

name: claire voon
reason: I joined artshack nearly 2 years ago in large part because of its mission, and it is deeply disappointing to see how, when faced with opportunities to intentionally uphold its values and better this much-needed creative space, leadership has instead chosen to silence and retaliate against its staff — people who are the everyday core of artshack’s care and operations. the director’s public response on May 13 is telling in its dismissiveness and condescension, emphasizing how it is long past time to undo the harmful, delusional hierarchies of this institution (and make it *not* an institution). I believe the opportunity for genuine reform still exists — the words here show how many of us do want to invest in and fight for artshack’s future as a space committed to serving all.

name: Liz Lagerfeld
reason:
Like Artshack, I am a relative newcomer to Bed Stuy. I love this community with my whole heart, but I also know that, as a white person who moved here in 2021, I have an uphill battle to contribute in any way. Like me, to have any prayer of doing more good than harm to Bed Stuy, Artshack needs to be actively, constantly, and humbly engaged in anti-racism. But that mission seems to have been lost.

I have seen this same breakdown happen in the nonprofit I work for: staff builds power and calls out racism and poor treatment of workers, and management tries to squash it. Not only is that wrong, but it also won't work. At my office, staff became so incensed that we unionized. At the same time, we called out racism publicly and our organization had a huge public relations crisis. The board brought in an outside ED. I hope McKendree Key and the board will learn from this lesson. If they continue on this path, at best they will be replaced. At worst, they will blow up the entire organization. Which would be a tragedy given its strength, potential, and beauty.

name: G G
reason:
I’ve never forgiven the owner for hanging those brown paper dolls on nooses in the window of her home. Had I known about that before I became a student at Artshack for about 6 or 7 cycles, I would have never spent my money here! (Thanks Reddit.)

How can a woman so careless be the leader of a non-profit arts organization that claims to foster community care within a rapidly gentrified historically Black neighborhood? 

As a Black and queer person, and fourth generation resident of Crown Heights and Bed-Stuy, I am disappointed in the ways that Artshack has continued to become yet another creative a space that perpetuates racial and economic segregation within the neighborhood under the guise of inclusivity. Given the outrageous hikes in pricing, my lived experience in the space (in which I often felt priced-out or unwelcomed, especially by the owner), and the recorded incidents in the Proton Drive, its clear to me that Artshack has completely fallen flat on it’s mission and a change in leadership is necessary.

name: Katie Cox
reason:
It is very easy for an institution to write "anti-racist" in it's mission statement.
It is less easy to embody the essence of this purported identity, especially in moments like the current moment at Artshack. Embodying anti-racism is a consistent, active practice, one that is at odds with the mainstream white supremacist capitalistic forces that the US was quite literally founded upon. I think often of Ta-Nehisi Coates' statement from his book Between the World and Me: "If you grow up in the US, you live and breathe racism." The work of dismantling white supremacy is like swimming upstream in a river -  it requires active work. It is active work that is crucial for our collective healing from the wounds and violent legacies of enslavement that exist in the bedrock of this country. 

I'm not a member of the Artshack community directly, but I am an artist living in Brooklyn, an organizer, an educator, and a person working to align my life with collective liberation. I am a white person living on unceded Lenape land, living and working in rapidly gentrifying neighborhoods undergoing the current violent displacement of Black, brown and indigenous residents. I'm interested in facing this reality, and working each day, in community with others, to get creative about what true solidarity and reparations must look like in order for us to be in right relationship to each other and this land.

I truly hope the Board of Artshack can set aside their egos and receive this community response to the recent chain of events for what it is: a gift. Being held accountable to something - receiving criticism that you are not doing what you said you would do, or that somewhere along the way, you went off track, or that what you are doing is causing harm - is valuable feedback, rooted in care, and should be treated as such. I hope the Artshack community can strengthen from this experience, and move towards a true embodiment of their stated values. We need art spaces that are TRULY anti-racist, TRULY queer-affirming, TRULY celebrating people of all abilities. None of these exist without the others.

name: Stephanie Watanabe
reason: As a former Bed-Stuy community member with friends who love this space, I’m signing this as an ally in support of meeting the demands of the folks who are standing up for what’s equitable and what best deserves the community.

name: Anitra Michelle ♥️
reason: Art is always important and it connects us via spirit. Never not necessary!

name: Heena  Sharma
reason: I am deeply disturbed by the behavior of Artshack's board and ED in the face of very reasonable asks of open dialogue and community-driven accountability. As "DEI" is essentially made illegal across this country, it is appalling to hear about the termination of Cameo, a Black woman staff member whose labor was happily used in service of anti-racism and diversity until it became inconvenient and uncomfortable. I'm outraged to see the ED's latest efforts to coerce staff with punitive measures and a culture of fear, while decrying any community building efforts that dare to speak honestly unless they are "officially" made (i.e. censored) by the Board/ED. As a student who has only been able to begin my ceramics journey because of the work study opportunity, I extend my solidarity to the courageous and principled Artshack community members who are fighting for its mission even in the thrall of this greater fascist moment.

name: Alyssa Ziobro
reason: This behavior has no place in this neighborhood or anywhere!

name: Mary Fix
reason: I was a member for 5 years but left due to frustrations of members concerns being dismissed by ED

name: Ruby Epler
reason:
I have been going to artshack for almost three years and view it as a third space and community space within a city that lacks and is losing those kinds of spaces everywhere. A hugely important part of the space is the staff and the commitments to anti racism that are in the mission statement. While I don’t have all the context for the current issues, I want to clearly and unequivocally say that my support is with all of artshacks staff- especially Cameo- and their requests and demands seem like the bear minimums to maintain Artshack as the space I love. Much support and solidarity,
-Ruby

name: Monette McKay
reason: Clay is my safe space and I have found a beautiful community at Artshack these past two years. If you knew the darkness I have been through, the healing I find in clay makes so much sense. The GIFT to be surrounded by bipoc, differently-abled bodies and folks, in such a usually “white able-bodied space”, (look around at other ceramic studios) and to have a place committed to inclusivity and anti-racism in a non-performative way is a major priority to me.

name: norman beauchard
role: Teacher; Bed-Stuy Community Member; Working Member

name: SeoKyeong Yoon
reason: “Hold fast to dreams, for if dreams die, life is a broken-winged bird that cannot fly.”

name: Becca Ellsworth
reason: I love the Artshack community and I want to make sure it is a safe protected space for everyone.

name: Emma Skoler
reason: I used to be a member of Artshack Cafe staff and witnessed a lot firsthand. I love the Artshack community and hope it stays and friendly and welcoming place.

name: Samantha  Tully
reason: I want Artshack to reflect the community. It’s a wonderful program and I’m really inspired by it, but I want staff who reflect the mission of Artshack organically and authentically.

name: Meadow Kaye
reason: This is so important to have these spaces! Especially in the current climate of the United States and the world. It's deeply disturbing thr amount of community's and institutions that have been totally failing their Diversity snd equality missions at a very interesting time for them to do so.

name: Naomi Nocera
reason: It’s important to me because it is important to our community.

name: Bernfried Rose
reason: Why not?

name: Nina  Rose
reason: I believe in karma.

name: Andres Villalon
reason: Because it is an arts organization that provides an important space for the people of Bed Stuy. Also because I send my child there for programming and I want to invest in programs and ensure that those programs are values-aligned and embodying the stated values and mission.

name: Jenny Tolan
reason: We must stand up for art and creativity in our community. It is the lifeblood that connects and bolsters us all.

name: Sherry Boone
reason: To be in community seeking truth honesty and love to have fun and to have the uncomfortable and necessary conversations

name: Grace Nam
reason: Art Shack has been called to cultivate beloved community to practice alignment living in a race-based country, in a historically Black neighborhood. This is a beautiful moment of practice for us all to rise and be called in to contribute towards embodying and shaping love and liberation as a community.

name: Alexandra Jones
reason: This community and its embodiment of the mission are too precious not to protect.

name: Adrienne Westwood
reason: Art Shack is a vibrant part of our community + I want to be sure values of equity and inclusion are upheld in all decisions + programs.

name: Sam Prasopthum
reason: I love our community and want to make sure our community is taken care of and voices are heard!

name: p m
reason: It’s important to see spaces reflect their goals and values in a sustainable way. It’s important for white business owners in Black neighborhoods to take a step back and reflect on what hearing the community could actually look and feel like. Actually putting the points of the mission statement into practice would have a massively positive impact on the community, but after learning what’s been happening at artshack, it reads a little hollow.

name: Cameron Wallace
reason: Artshack has become a safe space for me. It’s inspired me to a new purpose and passion. The staff, people who work there, and well as the community as a whole has made that possible. I hope that it can be a safe space for everyone who works there.

name: Taraney Vigil
reason: One of my friends was personally discriminated against by the director, and lost her job because of it. Would really love to see this organization, clean itself up.

name: Antoinette Wood Brown Wood
reason: It’s extremely Important that the community stays independent and empowered with cultural identity and integrity

name: tessie nam
reason: i was drawn to artshack when i saw anti racism in the mission. after experiencing the joy, connection and care in the community and then witnessing the harm and intimidation by leadership, i got curious and started asking questions. the “power-over” leadership became clear as i witnessed the fear and control come up when ppl didn’t fall in line. when being curious and asking questions is seen as threatening and wrong, how can anyone feel seen, heard and valued? even as i write this, the retaliation and lashing out continues… staff fired yesterday and the rest of the staff/community on high alert. an exhaustion of energies felt by all. i hope community conversations begin to repair and heal as we move toward better ways for all.

name: Shona Ortiz
reason: As former café staff, I wholeheartedly support the initiatives of Artshack’s staff and community! Whether on an interpersonal or organizational level, I believe in aligning actions with values, and I see this initiative as an invitation for reflection and actions that more meaningfully align with the values clearly outlined in Artshack’s stated mission.

name: Aisha King
role: Teacher; Student; Working Member; Volunteer; Ally

name: Nadia Mckinney
reason: Because it is important that as the cost of living increases and overt fascism and racism prevails that the community has an accessible and safe environment for all people to be in togetherness and tap into ceramics

name: Saadia Shaza
reason: The world needs more of this!

name: Adrian Bello
reason: Power dynamics that are related to race are incredibly insidious and potent in almost every community effort I have been involved in. These things happen and they need to be tended with care. It is clear that the people being affected most by these dynamics are not being heard and I support their call to not be silenced.

name: Gabriella Bulgarelli
reason: Because Artshack should be a place of relaxation, learning, and comfort. Not a place of unconcious bias, structural racism, and frankly a money grab.

name: Nelson Diaz
reason: The will of community should be represented in spaces that claim to serve and support that community

name: Abbey Walsh
reason: I have been an Artshack student and TA over the past 18 months. One of the primary reasons I decided to be part of Artshack, and not another Brooklyn ceramics studio, was its commitment to the local community as well as the values the studio stands for. I am in solidarity with the staff who seek to realign Artshack with its mission.

name: Von  Laveau
reason: Artshack's mission is not being followed through, which makes the organization so wonderful. It’s important to support the voices of the leaders of tomorrow. It’s a shame the ones leading today aren’t capable of following the mission statements they created.

name: Juniellia Jack
reason: I have begun dabbling in pottery and clay and would love to visit the studio one day! It seems like a safe space for EVERYONE

name: Emma Banta
reason:
It is the reason I came to Artshack instead of the many other ceramics studios in the New York area. 

I aspire to be part of a studio that connects to and works with and for the greater community around it.

name: Phil Ngo
reason:
Artshack’s mission and legacy of intentional community building and anti-racist policies has made it a uniquely suitable place to learn ceramics and build a community of artists. Artshack has been and should continue to be an intentionally welcoming space for people of color and the LGBTQ+ community.

I had a wonderful experience there in a beginner art class with my kids, wife, and sibling, who is a long time member. I have witnessed the remarkable strength of the community in my short term involvement and in my sibling’s continued longer-term involvement.

I hope Artshack leadership will prioritize decision making that respects its own mission and learns from community feedback, so that the community can continue to grow in a healthy and inclusive direction.

name: Mahirah Billah
reason: I believe all spaces should be committed to their mission and fully uphold the values they were founded on.

name: Chad Cannon
reason: Diversity is strength, financial transparency is honesty, and being accountable to the community the organization serves is integrity!

name: Tamara  Forrest
reason: Ceramics was by far one of my favorite classes in high school. 25 years later, my work, my energy and ingenuity still rests at my mom’s home. #TeamCameo #TeamDoRight

name: J Mentor
reason: Stand united.

name: Ellen Eberhardt
reason: A friend is employed there and I would like to support her and coworkers efforts!

name: Natalie Snodgrass
reason: it’s disheartening to learn that anyone in this community i care so much for has felt unsafe or unheard. I’m signing this petition with the deep hope that it will encourage the organization to recommit wholeheartedly and earnestly to the mission it has promised. it seems more important now than ever that Artshack exists as a bastion of racial equity, queer inclusion, and creativity opportunity for all people

name: Tivon Phillips
reason: Repressing and punishing artists through systemic racism and capitalistic exploitation under the guise of a “community based nonprofit” is very obviously wrong. I support Artshack, its talent and community principles in relation to leadership and inclusion. I support the demands and reforms waiting to be instituted for an Artshack that is truly accessible and revitalizing.

name: Roni Shabo
reason: If artshack is not a safe space for some, it is not a safe space for all.

name: Gabrielle Tang
reason: While the ceramics community in NYC has made efforts to remove barriers that have historically kept out POCs — particularly Black artists — from access to community studio spaces & classes, many studios still remain largely run with policies & cultures that have underlying white supremacist cores. Racially diversifying board and staff is one step, but the Artshack community also deserves a leader (or leaders) who approaches the community with compassion, openness, and humility instead of condescension and close-mindedness. These latter attributes, as currently exhibited by McKendree, signal to the Artshack community a holding onto of racist & anti-feminist beliefs — whether conscious or unconscious. The lack of conversation, let alone collaboration, with concerned members of the community is alarming about any leadership. The clay community in NYC is precious to me & I desire to see everyone flourish in their craft & their joy in clay. Therefore, it’s important to me to see studios be not only creative spaces but also spaces of compassion & joy-fostering. I stand with the community in wanting an appropriate space for them to make work & learn ceramics in safety & comfort.

name: Liysa Mendels
reason: Because no one is free until we are all free

name: Anny Chen
reason: They fired my partner at the height of Covid lockdown and are run by racists who have more internal work to do to unlearn white supremacy

name: Menemsha Thompson
reason: Artshack’s mission is what binds this vibrant artist community. Reflected in this petition is enormous love for Artshack and a fierce dedication to actualizing its potential. I am proud to be in community with Artshack artists and am inspired by their courage and grit. Hoping this leads to positive transformation.

name: August Mondale
reason: Artshack has an amazing community, and I support the efforts of the staff to maintain a positive space for everyone who visits.

name: Phillip Retuta
reason: To make everyone feel both safe and welcomed.

name: Mallory Banks
reason: While I learned how to throw at Artshack, I also went through several instances of undue racialized harm (including deeply upsetting run ins with members of leadership and staff) while I was a student (and TA) there. I deeply wanted Artshack to be a place that aligned with its stated mission, but it simply did not fulfill what it set out to do.

name: Amelia Pinney
reason: This is important to me because Art Shack’s mission is what creates a safe and welcoming space for us to gather. If we don’t stay true to that mission, the space loses what makes it so special.

name: Dana barnes
reason: As a black woman teaching artist and current student for it is important for me to stand up for the community that supports and aids into the development of black and brown students. I do not support organizations that are built on the foundation of black and brown communities but fail to meet the basic requirements to do so. furthermore given the demographic of artshack, it is VERY contradicting to preach that this mission is important to the community when it looks like only one person is benefiting from these changes. it’s the same story over and over again for generations - when will shit ACTUALLY change??

name: Charlotte Bowditch
reason:
Protecting and supporting members of my community is the most important thing in any organization. 
The people who work and worked at artshack are instrumental to the experience as a student, creating a supportive environment and encouraging creativity.
Everyone deserves to feel safe and heard. Artshacks mission to be antiracist and queer affirming is needed now more than ever.

name: Lateefah  Torrence
reason: In addition to the well-considered demands, I suggest that Artshack also establish a Community Advisory Board to provide balance to the governing structure. A community can't be served if it isn't heard.

name: Sheena Matheiken
reason: The Artshack community has been a huge part of my life the past 2 years. Artshack's mission is what brings this beautiful community together. It is in times of crisis that an organization's mission is truly tested, and the only way to uphold its promise is to engage in an open, honest and ongoing dialogue with its community, no matter how hard that may be. I hope this petition will be received as a sign of the commitment and willingness of all of us to actively participate in that difficult work. I hope this is a vital step toward Artshack’s growth and reconciliation.

name: LaShawn S.
reason: I made the decision to leave my previous studio because of Artshack's mission and what I perceived to be an earnest and honest accounting of what it means to live that out loud and with integrity. I have been fortunate that the folks I've met, including my teacher, have been committed to facilitating and upholding the mission of Artshack while expanding my love for clay. But it pains me to hear that that is not the reality for Artshack as a whole. With the state of the world, my class has been a real place of joy for me as has been my coffee breaks in the café. I'd implore Artshack leadership to listen to its community members who are operating from a space of wanting it to thrive. Brooklyn is losing many of its gathering spaces, especially those that recognize the violence of anti-Blackness and gentrification in our neighborhoods. We all are invested in seeing Artshack be a place that continues to offer members and students, adult and children, a space to be their best whole, selves while there. It's never too late to do the right thing. The good thing is the community has generously outlined what accountability and repair are needed to get Artshack there.

name: Jim Baek
reason: Art shack has an oppty to be a different type of nonprofit. A truly community based and driven organization vs. a more typical social services agency.

name: Nia Sanders
reason: As a former member/student at Artshack, a member of the bedside community, and a queer and Black woman within the broader ceramics community, I believe this mission is important in order to make this particular ceramics space as inclusive to all as possible, and this must include hearing and uplifting the voices of those who have been historically and presently silenced, and in doing so support And evolve the broader ceramics community by making it more universally inclusive and equitable as well. Accountability is such a huge part of this work, and as someone who believes in the mission of Artshack and has firsthand witnessed the positive work that has come from the organization, it’s critical that these moments where it is clear that conversation, action, and change needs to happen, that the mission (and the history that led to its current articulation) needs to be held at the center, and actively practiced by all who are involved, especially those who hold power within the community.

name: Mary Locke
reason: Artshack has been a wonderful place and I've appreciated the staff and community greatly. Adhering to the mission is necessary, especially as it relates to the history and future of Bedstuy. When Artshack can align with the mission, as many/most of the staff desire and perpetuate in their work, Artshack and the community can thrive together. It's at it's best when you see this alignment. When the mission is ignored, it's a betrayal to the community that has been curated there. I support conversations and actions that support the mission being taken seriously. Thank you to the teammembers, community, and allies who stand up for it.

name: Whitney Chandler
reason: I love Artshack! It's so important to keep our space open for the kids and our community and to stick to our mission!

name: Foluso Ogundepo
reason: Artshack is a vital community creative space. It is impartative that the workers who make it a safe community hub feel safe when they go to work. These vunerable workers are risking retaliation by taking this public, which makes it clear that McKendree Key has refused all internal attemps at accountability. She is uninterested in doing any real work to dismantle her own racism and bigotry. Mentioning anti-racism in the mission statment is performative - you actually have to practice what you preach. If you can't, then you are unfit to be in a leadership position. As a Brooklyn community memeber and ally, I fully support Art Shack's staff, and will do whatever I can to help ensure their demands are met. Sending support and love to the Artshack staff. We stand with you!

name: Tom Ngo
reason:
ArtShack isn’t a pottery studio that happens to be anti-racist and queer-affirming. It’s the converse. At its heart, it’s a community built on those values—equity, inclusion, care—and clay just happens to be the medium that brings people together.

For our child, it’s been a space of real connection and creativity for years. That point came home to us on our last visit from LA to NYC. I saw thriving affirmation of the belonging that they crave. 

Artshack's mission is to make art—but also to make room. That makes this initiative a pivotal, existential moment for the community. What is Artshack, and for what does it exist? The outcome of this referendum will be an answer to those questions.

name: Punit Lad
reason: The beauty of a neighbourhood comes in the form of spaces where people can create community, feel accepted and represent the diverse nature of said neighbourhood. Artshack is and has been one of these places and an important one in a community as diverse as BedStuy. The protection of a space like ArtShack is also the protection of the community it stands within. I stand with those of the ArtShack community and their demands.

name: Alfonso François
reason: I’ve spent over a year on ArtShack’s cafe staff and have met so many wonderful people during my time. It’s because of the amazing patrons and studio staff that I wanted to continue nurturing my newfound love for clay. It saddens me that the mission to develop accountability as an anti-racist, queer-affirming organization is met with what seems to be a direct conflict of human interest. One person’s vision created something beautiful in Bed-Stuy, a neighborhood I am from and have seen change significantly over the last 30+ years. With respect to the history of the neighborhood and its beautiful people, the community at ArtShack should impacted positively by its present. Once it becomes the opposite, then reflection and accountability is called for from those changing the tides. I hope to see the space and its people operate in the harmony it deserves. I truly love this place and speak highly of its offerings. Wishing nothing but the best.

name: Saoli Nguyen
reason: I have frequented Art Shack as a local friend and neighbor, and I know it as a welcoming, vibrant, and uplifting space. I strongly believe that this is due to the culture that has been created by the wonderful staff, teachers, volunteers, and community members. Art Shack would not be what it is without any of these people, and I'm very disappointed to learn that its leadership is undermining the very fabric of what makes this space amazing. I fully stand with the Art Shack community and will show my support in any way possible.

name: Leo Stratus
reason: Every moment I spend at Artshack with the people who keep it running each day, I am a better person for. Whether employee, worker-member, scholarship student, regular student, teacher, resident artist, friend - I am a better person for.

name: Brianna Soleyn
reason: We need a safe and welcoming spacece that’s not alienating to the surrounding community- that fosters and empowers workers and members rather than promoting toxicity and control!

name: Nathaniel Stoner
reason: I signed this petition because Artshack’s mission—to serve its community through inclusive, accessible, and equitable arts programming—is something I believe in deeply. That mission can only be realized when the leadership upholds the same values it claims to promote. It’s incredibly disheartening to see actions that contradict commitments to anti-racism and community care, especially when they impact the very people who make Artshack a meaningful and safe space. I stand in solidarity with the staff, artists, and community members calling for accountability, transparency, and restorative justice. This is about protecting the integrity of a space that should belong to everyone—especially those who have historically been excluded or harmed.

name: eliette  C
reason: McKendree Key claims to have created an anti-racist organization but creating an organization with unilateral control is not anti-racist. anti-racism is only formed in community, not by a tyrant. a community center should be community!

name: Naomi Day
reason: Artshack’s focus on bringing the transformative power of the earth (quite literally!!) into a historically Black community that has been attacked and demeaned and so much more is deeply meaningful to me both as an artist and as a community member committed to upholding liberation and interconnected relationship building in these contexts.

name: Erika Ngo
reason: ArtShack has been a safe place of creativity, friendship and joy for my child for many years. I have attended one fundraising event and was impressed with the body of work of its students and staff as well as the beautiful facility and the  anchor it is to the neighborhood. When so many people are hurting and cries for reform are this loud then positive action for change must occur. I support reform and sincere engagement to address the issues of racism and diversity and inclusion.

name: Adrian Elim
reason: Some friends of mine work at Artshack and I am a firm believer in workers rights, unions etc. besides with all the relentless gentrification currently ravaging our neighborhoods - these organizations need to be held to a higher standard if they plan to stay

name: Sarah Ngo
reason: Art Shack is a treasured safe space and source of community support for someone very dear to me, as I’m sure it is for so many others. Keep Art Shack a supportive, inclusive community!!

name: michael  dajour
reason: As a previous student, staff member, and now current working member that was introduced to clay through Artshack and the beautiful diverse community that it holds, it hurts to hear about the actions that have been taking place in this once holistic space. In a time where DEI actions are taking place, it is important that Artshack is held accountable to uphold the standards of the mission statement that is proudly waved on their website. If the mission statement is not being practiced on a daily basis, then it should be updated immediately instead of waving it around to continue receiving funding and grants that were giving to them on said premises. You should NOT be silencing people with retaliation for bringing awareness and accountability to your very eyes.

name: Noelani Fishman
reason: I’ve visited Artshack numerous times for events and always uplifted by the community. It’s a shame for that to be tainted

name: Savannah Ngo
reason: Communication is key. Cutting off communication is the sure downfall of any great organization. I hope the ED comes to the table, hears the concerns of the community, and responds as needed.

name: Phil Herbert
reason: Artshack is a critical part of the community - I have personally seen the hugely positive impact it has had on many friends, the importance it has in the neighbourhood, and the lifeline it represents to artists throughout Bed-Stuy.

name: fayola fair
reason:
you put these words in your mission statement. you decided to align yourself with anti-racist practice, now is the time to step up and be held
accountable for maintaining the mission YOU created.

name: Sara Parelhoff
reason: If Artshack is going to purport to be a net good for the community, then that must be backed up by action.

name: Mary Bess Pritchett
reason: In a time of consistent attacks on diversity, equity, inclusion, accessibility, and creative expression, spaces like Artshack are vital. And, if those in leadership at such a crucial community hub cannot create safe spaces for its staff, students, members, and their families, then accountability must be taken and grievances addressed. Sending all my support and gratitude to the Artshack staff and community!

name: Paige Hackworth
reason: Art shack should be an inclusive and safe place for everyone who attends.

name: Candice Bailey
reason: Every person, regardless of background, finances, or identity, deserves access to clay and art and the freedom, joys, and lessons that clay can teach us all.

name: Mars Dixon
reason: Artshack is my third place. It's my meditative space, my creative space, my community space. It's the first place I go when the cruelty/violence/white supremacy of the world is too heavy to bear and I feel like I need to cry but I'm on testosterone, so I can't cry easily so I pour all my would-be tears into my ceramics.

name: Binta Coulibaly
reason: Artshack is meant to be a safe space for the community. It's current leadership is forcing it to be a white supremacist, gentrifying force in the neighborhood.

name: Anna Letson
reason: Like many, Artshack's mission is what attracted me to the studio. The community I have found within Artshack is endlessly inspirational and supportive, and their dedication to and embodiment of the mission is what keeps this place alive. It is blatantly obvious and egregiously ironic that the executive director does not reflect those values. This leadership must be held accountable. Artshack deserves stewardship rooted in transparency, equity and care for the community it serves and fights to uplift.

name: Rikki  Amani
reason:
With so many places popping up in bedstuy severely lacking or neglecting direction toward a mission it is truly important that as community members we rally around the mission of anti-racism and queer affirming community space that art shack proposes in its statement. Although artshack can be perceived as a gentrifying project toward already minimized black and brown community members having such a mission in place (anti-racism, and other critical affiliations) can alleviate some of the cultural and communal tension. It is critical to practice, anti-racism and queer affirmation, especially in times that are so strife with political unrest and communal discourse. Already having incidents of racism in the past It is crucial that art 
shack fortifies their mission in this way to the community that has served it as well as it has served its community.

name: Judah Wilson
reason: Artshack is an excellent community gathering space. One which I hold fond memories in. The mission must not be lost or a true gem will be as well.
role: Bed-Stuy Community Member; Student; Volunteer; Ally

name: Atlas Thomas
reason: In a time where we are seeing the world slide further into fascism, it is important to form strong connections and stand with each other rather than let arbitrary differences separate us. For years, I thought I was working towards a brighter future under the guidance of Artshack's mission, making connections and spreading resources to the surrounding community, though now it seems that work was only for show. Given recent events, I am only more dedicated to the mission and I truly believe that staying aligned with these goals will make us stronger as a collective in the coming days, months, and years.

name: Kathleen  Malnati
reason: I'm grateful to have been brought into the work of the mission by the Artshack Community, and to continue showing up for it.

name: Gabriel Lee
reason: Artshack should be a haven in a terrible world, particularly for those most harmed by it.

name: kali block-steele
reason:
the mission is what brought me to artshack in the first place, and it’s the community of people i met that made me stay. 

as a student for over a year, i only recently learned who the executive director was.  it’s been deeply upsetting to learn of the immense harm this one person has caused to so many of the incredible people that make artshack what it is. 

i am devoted to the community that the PEOPLE of artshack have built, and will continue to fight to save that. now is not the time for the will of a single white woman to destroy a haven for hundreds that the people of this community have made possible.
role: Staff; Bed-Stuy Community Member; Student; Working Member

name: Leanne Gan
reason: I joined artshack because of its dedication to anti-racism through its programming, through its scholarships, and through its focus on community. My hope is that the community can be brought in to help be a part of the solution when problems arise. In a time when DEI initiatives are being rolled back, it’s imperative we stick to our values.

name: Angelique De Castro
reason: Artshack has been my haven for creativity and connection with this neighborhood. Over the years, it's been hard to witness and experience repeated patterns of harm that drove many of my friends and mentors away. It's never too late to come to the table a listen to each other with an open heart and intention to reaffirm Artshack's mission together.

name: MR Ngo
reason: I've met so many lovely, creative, cool, silly people at Artshack. And, the way I see it, the mission is a promise to invite in all of those people, make them feel welcome, listen to them, and protect them. Artshack leadership fails to live up to that promise, and that is why I stand in solidarity with the community members fighting to fix that.

name: Toby Glover
reason: Built upon the foundation of the mission, Artshack's people and positive atmosphere has fundamentally changed my perspective and the way I move through the world. Everyone deserves to have access to this space -- I am sure that adopting a more conservative mission will reduce the diversity of people who choose to enter this space.

name: sus adrian
reason: Artshack has become such an important place for many.. I want it to survive, to thrive, to live up to its full potential. A place where neighbors and newcomers feel welcome, staff sticks around long term and leaves with a good taste in their mouth, where true community is built, people know each other, and conflict is handled with honesty, directness, and accountability. A place that takes the mission of anti-racist queer-affirming and, I’d add, class justice seriously, as a daily action. Internal tension can be felt from the outside by students, parents, cafe patrons, neighbors, etc. Let’s stop pretending. Let’s make Artshack a place that long term residents of BedStuy are proud of. Let’s care for the few that were sacrificed for the many.

name: Corey Grad
reason: I have participated in fundraisers for Artshack and am disheartened to hear these cases where the organization has not lived up to its values. I stand with the Artshack community and fully support their demands.

name: Julia Thompson
reason: So the space and community are safe and accessible to everyone. Following the mission gives the organization the scaffolding it needs to be a part of the collective effort to dismantle white supremacy.

name: Jessika Stocker
reason: Artshack is my main source of income and community as I go through grad school. I’ve learned so much about myself and people in general from the Artshack community let alone what I’ve learned about clay and I don’t know what I would do without the members space and everyone in it. As a white woman, I will remain committed to being accountable and to hold others accountable to being anti-racist.
role: Teacher; Bed-Stuy Community Member; Working Member

name: Travis Nichols
reason: I came to Artshack when I REALLY needed it, and I can’t even begin to express how much it has meant to me. So when I started learning that my experience wasn’t universal, nopenopenope. It *must* exist out loud for everyone the way I (in my naivety) was. Artshack is necessary for so many people, and it is *absolutely necessary* for it to live its mission.

name: Anna Maconachy
reason: Artshack is so unique and special and that’s because of its mission and the people who stand behind it.

name: Christopher Combemale
reason: Artshack has been a major part of my life for the last 6 years, from the community of members to my beloved students. I want to see it continue to grow and be a happy, welcoming space for all, especially the staff who keep our wonderfully chaotic studio moving.

name: Joanna Choi
reason: Given Artshack’s history of racism, canceling anti-racism work would be a step in the wrong direction. What would Artshack’s place be in the neighborhood it occupies?
